2.text: Of a truth I know that it is so: But how can man be just with God?

3.text: If he be pleased to contend with him, He cannot answer him one of a thousand.

4.text: He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: Who hath hardened himself against him, and prospered?â€”

5.text: Him that removeth the mountains, and they know it not, When he overturneth them in his anger;

6.text: That shaketh the earth out of its place, And the pillars thereof tremble;

7.text: That commandeth the sun, and it riseth not, And sealeth up the stars;

8.text: That alone stretcheth out the heavens, And treadeth upon the waves of the sea;

9.text: That maketh the Bear, Orion, and the Pleiades, And the chambers of the south;

10.text: That doeth great things past finding out, Yea, marvellous things without number.

11.text: Lo, he goeth by me, and I see him not: He passeth on also, but I perceive him not.

12.text: Behold, he seizeth the prey, who can hinder him? Who will say unto him, What doest thou?

13.text: God will not withdraw his anger; The helpers of Rahab do stoop under him.

14.text: How much less shall I answer him, And choose out my words to reason with him?

15.text: Whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer; I would make supplication to my judge.

16.text: If I had called, and he had answered me, Yet would I not believe that he hearkened unto my voice.

17.text: For he breaketh me with a tempest, And multiplieth my wounds without cause.

18.text: He will not suffer me to take my breath, But filleth me with bitterness.

19.text: If we speak of strength, lo, he is mighty! And if of justice, Who, saith he, will summon me?

20.text: Though I be righteous, mine own mouth shall condemn me: Though I be perfect, it shall prove me perverse.

21.text: I am perfect; I regard not myself; I despise my life.

22.text: It is all one; therefore I say, He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.

23.text: If the scourge slay suddenly, He will mock at the trial of the innocent.

24.text: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked; He covereth the faces of the judges thereof: If it be not he, who then is it?

25.text: Now my days are swifter than a post: They flee away, they see no good,

26.text: They are passed away as the swift ships; As the eagle that swoopeth on the prey.

27.text: If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will put off my sad countenance, and be of good cheer;

28.text: I am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.

29.text: I shall be condemned; Why then do I labor in vain?

30.text: If I wash myself with snow water, And make my hands never so clean;

31.text: Yet wilt thou plunge me in the ditch, And mine own clothes shall abhor me.

32.text: For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, That we should come together in judgment.

33.text: There is no umpire betwixt us, That might lay his hand upon us both.

34.text: Let him take his rod away from me, And let not his terror make me afraid:

35.text: Then would I speak, and not fear him; For I am not so in myself.
